description: From Middle English snurten (“to sneer; snort, snore”), a variation of snorten (“to snort”). Compare also Norwegian snurt (“vexed, peevish”), Middle English snirt (“stern, gloomy”).

entries.meaning: (Scotland) A suppressed laugh; a sharp intake of breath.

verbs.description: snirt (third-person singular simple present snirts, present participle snirting, simple past and past participle snirted)

entries.meaning: (Scotland) To give a suppressed laugh or sharp intake of breath.
examples: "He grins, and snirts, and thraws ye ken —  I maist could die, wi' laughin."

entries.meaning: (Canada, US) Snow that is dirty, often seen by the side of roads and parking lots that have been plowed.
examples: We then have what we call ‘snirt’ storms.
